The doctor described in this piece sounded like he was quite humble and the first to admit he didn't have all the answers.

And good lord, everyone does die. That does not mean it is a doctor's failure. It is a fact of life!
Doesn't the bit about the pacemaker, the very existence and improvement thereof, undermine your whole argument?

Doctors like to think they know the answers. Not all the answers, but enough to treat the symptoms presented. But medical education doesn't teach humility. The more we know, the less our acquired medical knowledge should dominate decision-making.

I just received my second pacemaker. The differences between device technology of 2006 and 2013 are startling, and represent a real challenge to the cardiologists to learn how to optimize the results. Complexity is added by interactions between "blocker" drugs, such as carvedilol and ilbesartan and pacemakers. Because of frequent improvements in devices, experience with a given device is not anywhere as great as experience with the drugs. Both drugs are now patent-expired, meaning they have been studied for a dozen years.

There is more art than science in medical practice. This creates a higher degree of uncertainty about optimum outcomes than the physician is willing to admit in seeking to gain compliance by the patient. The doctor isn't necessarily in the wrong on this, because--even with the uncertainties--the doctor is usually much better equipped to make the choices.

The problems come when the results are sub-optimum, and the doctor is thrown back unto reliance upon studies--often drug-manufacturer paid--for guidance. Results are measured in how long the patient lives with good quality of life. Everyone dies, of course, one to a customer, so ultimately all the doctor's efforts still result in some form of failure.

Calvin,

Is the quadratic formula conservative? Are Newton's laws liberal?

The IS/LM model is not ideological. It is neither liberal, nor conservative. It is mathematical. The IS/LM model can be used to make predictions -- for example, predictions about what the consequences will be when certain fiscal or monetary policies are applied to an economy in a certain condition.

How well, or how poorly these predictions correspond to the unfolding of events, is mainly a mathematical question -- not an ideological one!

Mr. Krugman, and other adherents of this model (which has been around for about 75 years) have repeatedly made predictions that have proved impressively accurate, especially since the recession/depression hit in 2008. Further, these predictions were and are VERY DIFFERENT from those made by other macroeconomic models, so this has been a good test of the model's validity.

These facts are available to anyone who will take the time to do some reading. If you can demonstrate that other models made better predictions, we look forward to seeing your data!

If I put a hamster in an aquarium, the poor creature might drown. If California = France = Greece = USA, then the sweaty panic of the people who hate Krugman's policy advice makes sense. What would you say about a class of 5th graders, that was unable to find some very important differences among these various economic systems?

Today is a good day, to begin your education!

I have a similar response as Patricia in Pasadena, based on my grandmother who was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis in mid life. Her approach with n=1 was thoroughly sophisticated and scientific.

She noticed the doctor's mother was on a wheelchair because of rheumatoid arthritis. She concluded that if the doctor could not help his own mother she was on her own. After noticing that diet affected symptoms she "invented" the scientific method by methodically controlling variables over a long period of time. She removed food items from her diet for weeks at a time and kept notes on symptoms and then reintroduced them until she verified if they affected her arthritis. Over a period of several months she arrived at a diet that she kept to the end of her life. She died at 89 without ever spending a single hour on a wheelchair. Lifetime cost to insurance for medicine = zero.

Preparing food was the first order of business everyday because she did not want to make food decisions when hungry. She controlled both what and how much to eat . So she prepared her lunch and dinner in the morning and never deviated from the regiment she carefully had devised. She also developed a protocol for daily physiotherapy to go with the diet.

She had not gone to medical school and in fact she did not learn how to read and write until her late twenties when my grandfather taught her how to read. She was very smart and open minded and I learned from her a healthy skepticism towards doctors.

Thank you, Matthew, for writing this article.  I have been hurting for Colin due to the articles written betraying Colin's birth mother as a sympathetic figure whom Colin should contact.  Most of them have been indirectly suggesting he do so, in the hopes of some heartwarming dramatic meeting.    The article you addressed was very direct and offensive.   I am a 37 year old adoptee, who is now a mother, and while I have had my "curious" moments (what do they look like, what do they do), none those moments have led me to meet my birth parents, even though I have the information.  Even when both of my adoptive parents died, I did not seek them out.  I, like Colin, had a 19 year old birth mother and an absent birth father.   Contrary to Mr. Reilly's opinion,  an adoptee does not have to meet his/her birth parents to be complete, nor do adoptees owe their birth parents anything.    To even suggest this is unconscionable.  While I appreciate the sacrifice my birth mother made, it is such a deeply personal decision to contact her, the most personal decision for an adoptee.   I really wish the media would focus only on his talent and football, and not something so excruciatingly difficult.   There are so many other less delicate sub story lines to the Superbowl worthy of an article.  Sincerely, Another conflicted heart.

You may enjoy a post in which I talked with Pete Seeger about Whitehead -- focusing on his notion that a society that does not value "trained intelligence" was doomed.

All good and reasonable advice.

But for someone interested both in math and saving the planet, I'd suggest the young student look into the work of Alfred North Whitehead and the philosophical tradition that has been influenced by him.

Whitehead, of course, was a mathematical physicist and wrote with Bertrand Russell PRINCIPIA MATHEMATICA. But he also developed a set of philosophical ideas that lay a foundation for ecological thinking -- in a way that classically "modern" thought does not.

For anyone interested in both mathematics and ecology, Whitehead and those who have come after him and stand in the "process thought" tradition are key.
